Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story:
The snow was coming down harder than I’d seen all winter, swirling in thick sheets across the windshield. My passenger, a nervous businessman, kept glancing at his watch and muttering about missing his flight. I gripped the wheel, trying to focus on the slippery road, but my phone buzzed again in the cupholder. Another message from my stepbrother: “Dinner’s starting soon. Mom’s asking where you are.” I could picture them all at the table, the warmth of the kitchen, the expectation that I’d be there, part of the family, not just the outsider who always had an excuse.

But I couldn’t just abandon my passenger, not in this weather, not when he was counting on me to get him to the airport safely and on time. Every red light, every slow crawl behind a snowplow, I felt the pressure mounting from both sides. I was supposed to be reliable, present for my family, but also professional, responsible for my passenger’s journey. My heart thudded with guilt and frustration as I weighed the demands, the storm outside mirroring the turmoil inside me.
